subject: Self Care
title: Guilt as a Compass
description: A quick, practical guide to Guilt as a Compass.

hook.text: She said no and felt guilty for three days. Her therapist said: 'Good. Guilt means you're breaking an old pattern.'

buildup.text: Guilt after setting a boundary doesn't mean you did something wrong. It means you did something new.

discovery.text: There are two types of guilt: healthy guilt from actual harm and conditioned guilt from defying old expectations.

twist.text: If you feel guilty every time you say no, the guilt is conditioned, not moral. It's discomfort from growth, not wrongdoing.

climax.text: Next time boundary guilt arrives, sit with it. Don't undo the boundary. Let the guilt pass. It fades faster than you think.

punchline.text: Guilt after saying no means growth, not wrongdoing. Let it pass.

quiz.question: What does guilt after setting a boundary usually indicate?
options: You're breaking a conditioned pattern, which is actually growth
You should reverse the boundary immediately
